DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Urged to Apologize or Resign
Eds: SUBS 1st graf to clarify by adding ``chief.'' SUBS 7th graf to add that reported comment was in an interview. Note language in 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff Allen Sloan should either apologize for a racial slur a newspaper said he made and hire a black chief deputy, or resign, business and civic leaders say. The Richland County sheriff has denied making the remark attributed to him by The State newspaper on Dec. 22 and said Thursday he would take neither action recommended by the Greater Columbia Community Relations Council. The council prefers that Sloan stay in office, said its chairman, Paul Beazley. Sloan said he was shown the council's statement shortly before its release and was appalled to hear that its conclusions and recommendations were unanimous and backed by the executive committee of the Greater Columbia Chamber of Commerce. ``As for the apology, I have already made an apology numerous times through the media and would like to take this opportunity as well to say that anything that was said to cause embarrassment to the black community or the white community, that I am truly sorry and apologize for it,'' Sloan said. ``I am everybody's sheriff,'' he said. ``I was elected by the whites and the blacks.'' The State reported that when asked in an interview in his office how safety could be improved at Columbia Mall, where four shootings have occurred in the past six months, Sloan replied: ``Keep the niggers out.'' Sloan has maintained he did not make the racial slur and said no one on the council consulted him before concluding that he had. The Community Relations Council said Thursday that if Sloan stays in office he should hire a black second-in-command, partly to advise him on race relations. The sheriff said he would not do that. ``There is no way that I'm going to let any group of citizens tell me how to hire or promote in this office, especially in stepping over the bounds in thinking it had to be someone black,'' Sloan said. ``I am not going to fire my chief deputy simply to hire someone because of a color. That's racial discrimination in its purest form right there.'' The Community Relations Council wichland County Council. Sloan, elected in 1988 to a four-year term, is the chief law enforcement officer in Richland County. The county, where the capital city of Columbia is located, is the third-most populous county in the state with 285,000 residents.
